docs.lead_paragraph: The budget agreement would make vast changes in Medicare, offering new health insurance options to the elderly, broadening coverage of preventive services and creating strong new financial incentives for managed care companies to serve people in rural areas. Beneficiaries would pay slightly higher costs, but not nearly as much as they would have been required to pay under the budget bill that President Clinton vetoed in December 1995.

headline.main: New Options Include Shift Into Preventive Benefits, and Slightly Higher Costs
headline.kicker: THE BUDGET DEAL: Details of Some Provisions Covering Children, Health, and Welfare -- MEDICARE

docs.abstract: Federal budget accord calls for vast changes in Medicare; would offer new health insurance options to elderly, broaden coverage of preventive services and create strong financial incentives for managed care companies to serve rural areas; beneficiaries would pay slightly higher costs; accord drops proposals to increase premiums for higher-income beneficiaries, raise eligibility age and impose new fee for home health care services (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton and the Republican leaders of Congress jubilantly -- but separately -- celebrated today their long-sought agreement on a plan to balance the Federal budget after decades of deficit spending and to provide the first Federal tax cut in 16 years. ''We have put America's fiscal house in order again,'' an ebullient President Clinton proclaimed on the south lawn of the White House where he was surrounded by about 100 Democrats from the House and Senate. Grinning and giving the Democrats a thumbs-up sign, he called the deal ''an historic agreement that will benefit generations of Americans.''

headline.main: Clinton and G.O.P. Cheer Plan to Balance Budget

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders separately celebrate accord on plan to balance Federal budget and cut taxes; Pres Clinton is surrounded by some 100 Democratic members of Congress as he hails plan; Republicans hail pact as culmination of their quest to cut Government's size and power; pact is expected to win majority votes from each party with some liberal Democrats as most prominent dissenters; Rep Richard A Gephardt, House minority leader, is noticeably absent from Clinton's side; photos (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton and the Republican leaders of Congress jubilantly -- but separately -- celebrated today their long-sought agreement on a plan to balance the Federal budget after decades of deficit spending and to provide the first Federal tax cut...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation has agreed to pay about $100 million to former patients who contended that the company and some affiliated doctors illegally imprisoned them in psychiatric hospitals in order to obtain their insurance benefits, people briefed on the financial arrangements said yesterday. As part of the resolution of lawsuits brought by about 700 former patients in two Texas state courts, the doctors have also agreed to pay the former patients about $20 million in compensation, these people said.

headline.main: $100 Million Settlement Seen In Tenet Suits

docs.abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp agrees to pay about $100 million to former patients who contend that company and some affiliated doctors illegally imprisoned them in psychiatric hospitals in order to obtain their insurance benefits; doctors also agree to pay former patients about $20 million in compensation; suits were brought by about 700 former patents in two Texas state courts, and settlements, which were reached in recent weeks, include strict terms imposed by Tenet and doctors to keep details secret; activities covered by settlements took place under former management of company, which was then known as National Medical Enterprises; Tenet is starting aggressive negotiations to acquire Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, nation's largest hospital chain (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Employee compensation costs rose slightly this spring because of an increase in benefits, but the gain posed no inflationary threat, Government figures showed today. ''There is just a slight amount of upward creep'' in pay packages, said L. Douglas Lee, chief economist for HSBC Washington Analysis, a securities firm. ''But we've managed to offset that with good productivity growth, strong competitive pressures and lower energy costs.''

headline.main: U.S. Reports Slight Increase In Wage Costs

docs.abstract: Labor Dept's quarterly survey of employment costs shows that employee compensation costs rose slightly this spring because of increase in benefits, but that gain poses no inflationary threat; L Douglas Lee, chief economist for HSBC Washington Analysis, says 'slight amount of upward creep' in pay packages is offset by good productivity growth, strong competitive pressures and lower energy costs; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton got his way on many of the big disputes over Federal spending, while Congressional Republicans prevailed on the tax issues about which they care most deeply. That appears to be the secret of the success announced tonight by budget and tax negotiators from the White House and Capitol Hill.
docs.abstract: Analysis of budget agreement beteen White House and Congress; Pres Clinton gets his way on many of big disputes over Federal spending, while Congressional Republicans prevail on tax issue about which they care most deeply (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans and the Clinton Administration agreed tonight on how to balance the budget for the first time in nearly three decades and on the first major tax cuts since 1981. Congress is likely to approve the plan this week. Among its highlights are a $500-per-child tax credit, significant cuts in capital gains and inheritance taxes, $1,500 scholarships for each of the first two years of college for middle-income students and $24 billion for children's health care.

headline.main: WHITE HOUSE AND THE G.O.P. ANNOUNCE DEAL TO BALANCE BUDGET AND TO TRIM TAXES

docs.abstract: Congressional Republicans and Clinton Administration reach agreement on ways to balance budget for first time in nearly three decades and on ways to cut taxes significantly for first time since 1981; Congress is likely to approve plan, which includes $500-per-child tax credit, reduction of maximum capital gains tax to 18 percent, lower inheritance taxes, 15 percent per pack increase in cigarette tax and a compromise on how much discretion states will have in deciding how to provide children's health insurance; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Seven weeks after selling its big home and automobile insurance unit, the Lincoln National Corporation said yesterday that it was buying most of the Cigna Corporation's individual life insurance business for $1.4 billion. Emblematic of the consolidation that is sweeping the insurance industry, the deal contributes to the plans of both Lincoln National and Cigna to reshape their organizations. As Cigna is moving away from individual life insurance toward a greater emphasis on employee benefits and other corporate sales, Lincoln National is widening its base as a financial services company focusing on individuals.

headline.main: Lincoln National Set to Acquire Bulk of a Cigna Business

docs.abstract: Lincoln National Corp to buy most of Cigna Corp's individual life insurance business for $1.4 billion; Lincoln chairman Ian M Rolland comments (M)
